TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {16280=On May 13, 1989, Mt. Taebaeksan's 17.44 ? land area was designated as Provincial Park. It provides accommodation including condominium-type lodging facilities, restaurants and picnic sites. It also houses the Coal Museum, where you can learn about the history of coal. In winter, a large-scale snow sledding site is prepared.}
textBeforeTable: Mountain Climbing Course   A mountain from which people prayed to heaven is called bakepan, meaning bright mountain. The largest and brightest is called tabaeksan. Mt. Taebaeksan was originally called 'hangbarkmoe' or 'hanvaedal,' meaning too bright. It was also called Hambaksan, Jakyaksan and Gyechongsan, and during the Silla kingdom it was called 'Bukak,' meaning the five mountains in the north. Name Mt. Taebaeksan shares its boundary with the following regions: Daehyeon-ri, Seokpo-myeon, Bonghwa-gun, Gyeongsangbuk-do ; Mungoksodo-dong, Taebaek-si; and Cheonpyeong-ri, Sangdong-myeon, Yeongwol-gun, Gangwondo Province. Mt. Taebaeksan, 1,567 meters above sea level, is located between 128¡ã56¡äeast longitude and 37¡ã05¡änorth latitude. The water originating from this mountain forms the Nakdonggang, lifespring of the Yeongnam plain. It also forms the Hangang and Osip Stream, and thus serves as the nation's spiritual mountain, and a root for all mountains, located in the southern part of the Koran peninsula. Centering on Yeongbong where Cheonjedan is located, Mt. Taebaeksan is comprised of Janggunbong peak (1568 meters above sea level) in the north, Munsubong peak (1,517 meters above sea level) in the east and Busoebong peak (1,546 meters above sea level) in between. With fewer cliffs and smooth slopes, everybody regardless of age
